        Parameters:

        number - The number to delete.

      • applyBlockPermutation

        public void applyBlockPermutation(Grid grid,
                                  Cell[] image)
        The method applies a block permutation on the grid using a cell array, called image.. First, a new grid (newGrid) is created which will make the assigning of the values easier. Next, check whether there is a horizontal or a vertical permutation to be applied. Do this by checking the column index of the first two elements of the image (which stand for the coordinates of the blocks which get assigned to the the blocks with anchor cells 1,1 and 1,4). If neither of them has changed, we must be dealing with a vertical permutation. If there is a horizontal permutation, apply the image by checking the first three anchor cells in the image and copy all the values row-wise (top to bottom) into the new grid while taking the permutation into consideration. Analogously for the vertical permutation.
        Specified by:
        applyBlockPermutation in interface BlockIsoUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to apply the permutation on. This is the grid to apply the Block Permutation on.
        image - The image to use. Use this image to apply the Block permutation.

      • isBlockPermutation

        public boolean isBlockPermutation(Grid grid1,
                                  Grid grid2)
        The solution of this function makes use of the fact that there are only 11 possible Block Permutations. (10 + 1 which is the ID) It applies all 11 images on grid1 and compares those with grid2. If any of them match, grid2 is the result of a grid1 block Permutation
        Specified by:
        isBlockPermutation in interface BlockIsoUtil
        Parameters:
        grid1 - The original grid.
        grid2 - The grid to compare to. The grid to compare to, once permutated.
        Returns:
        Returns true if grid2 is a block permutation of grid1, otherwise false.

        g2 - grid 2.
        Returns:

      • applyBlockValuePermutation

        public void applyBlockValuePermutation(Grid grid,
                                       Cell anchor,
                                       int[] image)
        By going through each cell of the block, set the value as dictated by the image (only if it is not empty).
        Specified by:
        applyBlockValuePermutation in interface BlockIsoUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to apply the Value permutation on
        anchor - The anchor determines the block to apply the value permutation on
        image - Is used to apply the permutation

      • getBlockValuePermutationImage

        public int[] getBlockValuePermutationImage(Grid grid1,
                                           Grid grid2,
                                           Cell anchor)
        First, the method initializes a default image full of -2, which stands for "undefined". Then, it compares two cells with the same coordinates in both grids. If both cells are filled, take a look at the image. If it has been defined (i.e. it is not -2 anymore), then the value of the cell in grid2 must match the definition in the image at index "[value-1]". If it doesn't, there is no valid value permutation. The method only returns an image if there is an output value for every input value. At the end, after replacing the -2 entries with -1, make sure that no two different input numbers point to the same output number in the image. If there is such a case, again: no value permutation could have taken place between those two grids.
        Specified by:
        getBlockValuePermutationImage in interface BlockIsoUtil
        Parameters:
        grid1 - The original grid.
        grid2 - The output.
        anchor - The anchor determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns the image that led to the permutation.

      • isBlockValuePermutation

        public boolean isBlockValuePermutation(Grid grid1,
                                       Grid grid2,
                                       Cell anchor)
        First, the method initializes a default image full of -2, which stands for "undefined". Then, it compares two cells with the same coordinates in both grids. If both cells are filled, take a look at the image. If it has been defined (i.e. it is not -2 anymore), then the value of the cell in grid2 must match the definition in the image at index "[value-1]". If it doesn't, there is no valid value permutation. The method only returns "true" if there is an output value for every input value. After replacing the -2 entries with -1, make sure that no two different input numbers point to the same output number in the image. If there is such a case, again: no value permutation could have taken place between those two grids.
        Specified by:
        isBlockValuePermutation in interface BlockIsoUtil
        Parameters:
        grid1 - grid1 is the original grid.
        grid2 - grid2 is the possible result of a value permutation in grid1,
        anchor - Determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns true if grid2 is the result of a value permution of grid1.

      • isValidBlock

        public boolean isValidBlock(Grid grid,

      • hasFullHouseBlock

        public boolean hasFullHouseBlock(Grid grid)
        The method isFullHouseBlock is being applied for each of the 9 blocks in the grid. If any of them are a Full House Block, the method returns true.

      • isFullHouseBlock

        public boolean isFullHouseBlock(Grid grid,
                                Cell anchor)
        The first condition to be met is that the block must be valid. So isValidBlock is being called. Next, the method goes through each of the cells in the block and counts how many of them are empty. If there are exactly 1, then this block is a Full House Block.
        Specified by:
        isFullHouseBlock in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to check.
        anchor - The anchor cell determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the block is a full house block.

      • crossOutCandidatesR

        public java.lang.Integer[] crossOutCandidatesR(java.lang.Integer[] candidates,
                                               int r,
                                               Grid grid)
        This method is being used in the Naked/Hidden Pair methods and checks which numbers appear in the row where the current cell is located. The method receives an array with size 9 which codifies the candidates by either 0 (candidate) or 1(not a candidate). The index of the array indicates which number is concerned. So for example, if a given number appears somewhere in the row, the respective index in the array is being assigned 1.
        Parameters:
        candidates - An array of length 9. Each index stands for a number and if it is 0, that means that it is a candidate for the current cell.
        r - The row to check.
        grid - The grid used.
        Returns:
        Returns the list "candidates" with the updated entries.

      • crossOutCandidatesC

        public java.lang.Integer[] crossOutCandidatesC(java.lang.Integer[] candidates,
                                               int c,
                                               Grid grid)
        This method is being used in the Naked/Hidden Pair methods and checks which numbers appear in the column where the current cell is located. The method receives an array with size 9 which codifies the candidates by either 0 (candidate) or 1(not a candidate). The index of the array indicates which number is concerned. If a given number appears somewhere in the column, the respective index in the array is being assigned 1.
        Parameters:
        candidates - An array of length 9. Each index stands for a number and if it is 0, that means that it is a candidate for the current cell.
        c - The column to check
        grid - The grid used.
        Returns:
        Returns the list "candidates" with the updated entries.

      • crossOutCandidatesB

        public java.lang.Integer[] crossOutCandidatesB(java.lang.Integer[] candidates,
                                               int r,
                                               int c,
                                               Grid grid)
        This method is being used in the Naked/Hidden Pair methods and checks which numbers appear in the block where the current cell is located. The method receives an array with size 9 which codifies the candidates by either 0 (candidate) or 1(not a candidate). The index of the array indicates which number is concerned. If a given number appears somewhere in the block, the respective index in the array is being assigned 1.
        Parameters:

        r - Helps indicate the block to check.
        c - Helps indicate the block to check.
        grid - The grid used.
        Returns:
        Returns the list "candidates" with the updated entries.

      • isBlockWithNakedSingleCell

        public boolean isBlockWithNakedSingleCell(Grid grid,
                                          Cell anchor)
        Keep track of the candidates for each cell by creating a special list: cellCandList will contain all the candidates for a given cell in the format: {0,0,0,0,1,0,0,1,1} means this cell accepts all the numbers except for 5,8 and 9. In other words, the index of the array indicates the number. 0 means it is a candidate and 1 means it is not. For every number from 1-9 k check whether it appears only once in a cell, if yes, return true.
        Specified by:
        isBlockWithNakedSingleCell in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to check.
        anchor - The anchor cell determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the block has a naked single cell.

      • getBlockNakedSingleCell

        public Cell getBlockNakedSingleCell(Grid grid,
                                    Cell anchor)
        Keep track of the candidates for each cell by creating a special list: cellCandList will contain all the candidates for a given cell in the format: {0,0,0,0,1,0,0,1,1} means this cell accepts all the numbers except for 5,8 and 9. In other words, the index of the array indicates the number. 0 means it is a candidate and 1 means it is not. For every number from 1-9 k check whether it appears only once in a cell, if yes, return the cell. At the beginning of the method we start looking from the cell with the lowest coordinates, Thus, it is guaranteed that the cell returned will be minimal.
        Specified by:
        getBlockNakedSingleCell in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to check.
        anchor - The anchor cell determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns the minimal naked single cell.

      • isBlockWithHiddenSingleCell

        public boolean isBlockWithHiddenSingleCell(Grid grid,
                                           Cell anchor)
        Keep track of the candidates for each cell by creating a special list: cellCandList will contain all the candidates for a given cell in the format: {0,0,0,0,1,0,0,1,1} means this cell accepts all the numbers except for 5,8 and 9. In other words, the index of the array indicates the number. 0 means it is a candidate and 1 means it is not. Next, check for every number k 1-9 if there is only once cell that accepts that k. Put that cell into a list. Finally, if the list is not empty, there is a hidden single cell.
        Specified by:
        isBlockWithHiddenSingleCell in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid used.
        anchor - The anchor cell determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the block has a hidden single cell.

      • getBlockMinimalHiddenSingleCell

        public Cell getBlockMinimalHiddenSingleCell(Grid grid,
                                            Cell anchor)
        Keep track of the candidates for each cell by creating a special list: cellCandList will contain all the candidates for a given cell in the format: {0,0,0,0,1,0,0,1,1} means this cell accepts all the numbers except for 5,8 and 9. In other words, the index of the array indicates the number. 0 means it is a candidate and 1 means it is not. Next, check for every number k 1-9 if there is only one cell that accepts that k. Put that cell into a list. Finally, search for the hidden single cell with the lowest coordinates and return that.
        Specified by:
        getBlockMinimalHiddenSingleCell in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid used.
        anchor - The anchor cell determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns a single hidden cell with the lowest coordinates.

      • isBlockWithNakedPair

        public boolean isBlockWithNakedPair(Grid grid,
                                    Cell anchor)
        Keep track of the candidates for each cell by creating a special list: cellCandList will contain all the candidates for a given cell in the format: {0,0,0,0,1,0,0,1,1} means this cell accepts all the numbers except for 5,8 and 9. In other words, the index of the array indicates the number. 0 means it is a candidate and 1 means it is not. Then, for each list, check if it contains exactly 2 candidates. If that's the case, add it to a potential list of naked pairs (listNaked) and also save their candidate lists into (cellCandList). Then, compare every cell's candidate list in "listNaked" with all the others'. If there is an exact match of candidate lists, return true. If there is no match at the end of the loop, return false.
        Specified by:
        isBlockWithNakedPair in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to check.
        anchor - The anchor determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the block has a naked pair.

      • getBlockNakedPairCells

        public Cell[] getBlockNakedPairCells(Grid grid,
                                     Cell anchor)
        Keep track of the candidates for each cell by creating a special list: cellCandList will contain all the candidates for a given cell in the format: {0,0,0,0,1,0,0,1,1} means this cell accepts all the numbers except for 5,8 and 9. In other words, the index of the array indicates the number. 0 means it is a candidate and 1 means it is not. Then, for each list, check if it contains exactly 2 candidates. If that's the case, add it to a potential list of naked pairs (listNaked) and also save their candidate lists into (cellCandList). Then, compare every cell's candidate list in "listNaked" with all the others'. If there is an exact match of candidate lists, that is a naked pair. Return the first match as it is guaranteed that the cell with the lowest coordinates will be saved before any other cell (just like in the method getBlockNakedSingleCell).
        Specified by:
        getBlockNakedPairCells in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to check.
        anchor - The anchor determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns the coordinates of the lowest member of a naked pair.

      • isBlockWithHiddenPair

        public boolean isBlockWithHiddenPair(Grid grid,
                                     Cell anchor)
        Keep track of the candidates for each cell by creating a special list: cellCandList will contain all the candidates for a given cell in the format: {0,0,0,0,1,0,0,1,1} means this cell accepts all the numbers except for 5,8 and 9. In other words, the index of the array indicates the number. 0 means it is a candidate and 1 means it is not. Go through each cell in the block and complete all 9 candidate lists by calling the methods crossOutCandidatesR, crossOutCandidatesC and crossOutCandidatesB (which check which numbers have already been put in a place that disqualifies them as candidates. For more information, go to the descriptions of those methods). Once the lists are complete, go through all the numbers 1-9 and check in how many candidate lists they appear. If they appear in exactly two candidate lists, put the respective cells into a new list, called "listHiddenCells". Then, search for matching pairs by looking at their coordinates. If two cells appear twice as a pair (i.e. next to each other in "listHiddenCells", they are a hidden pair. Put those into a final hidden pair list. If the list is having at least 2 entries, then return true for the entire method.
        Specified by:
        isBlockWithHiddenPair in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to check.
        anchor - The anchor determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the block has a hidden pair.

      • getBlockHiddenPairCells

        public Cell[] getBlockHiddenPairCells(Grid grid,
                                      Cell anchor)
        Keep track of the candidates for each cell by creating a special list: cellCandList will contain all the candidates for a given cell in the format: {0,0,0,0,1,0,0,1,1} means this cell accepts all the numbers except for 5,8 and 9. In other words, the index of the array indicates the number. 0 means it is a candidate and 1 means it is not. Go through each cell in the block and complete all 9 candidate lists by calling the methods crossOutCandidatesR, crossOutCandidatesC and crossOutCandidatesB (which check which numbers have already been put in a place that disqualifies them as candidates. For more information, go to the descriptions of those methods). Once the lists are complete, go through all the numbers 1-9 and check in how many candidate lists they appear. If they appear in exactly two candidate lists, put the cells into a new list, called "listHiddenCells". Then, search for matching pairs by looking at their coordinates. If two cells appear twice as a pair (i.e. next to each other in listHiddenCelld), they are a hidden pair. At the end, pick the pair with the minimal coordinates and return it.
        Specified by:
        getBlockHiddenPairCells in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to check.
        anchor - The anchor determines the block.
        Returns:
        Returns the cell pair with the minimal coordinates.

      • update

        public void update(Grid grid,
                   int clearNumber)
        Note: as of now not in use. Similarly to the createGlobalList method, the method clears the global candidate list of any numbers that are already used.
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to update.
        clearNumber - The number to delete from the candidate list.

      • solveBlockBasedWithoutStep0

        public Grid solveBlockBasedWithoutStep0(Grid grid,
                                        java.util.List<Grid> grids)
        A complete copy of solveBlockBased with the only difference being that it doesn't add the current grid to the list at the very beginning of the method. For convenience reasons related to the recursive approach to the solver method.
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to solve.
        grids - Needed to add the next grid to the grid list.
        Returns:
        Returns a grid which is one step closer to being solved.

      • solveBlockBased

        public java.util.List<Grid> solveBlockBased(Grid grid)
        0. The method creates a global candidate list. 1. It checks whether the grid is complete and valid using the completeAndValid method.. 2. It looks if there is a full house block; if yes, it fills it using fillNakedSingle. 3. By going through each anchor cell, it looks if there is a block with a naked single. If yes, it fills it using fillHiddenSingle. 4. By going through each anchor cell, it looks if there is a block with a hidden single. If yes, it fills it using fillHiddenCell. 5.(In development): By going through each anchor cell, it looks if there is a block with a naked pair. If yes, it updates the candidate list of all the related cells using useNakedPair. 6.(In development): By going through each anchor cell, it looks if there is a block with a hidden pair.
        Specified by:
        solveBlockBased in interface BlockSolvingUtil
        Parameters:
        grid - The grid to solve.
        Returns:
        Returns a list of grids that document the change in the grid throughout the method.

      • useNakedPair

        public void useNakedPair(Grid grid,
                         int r,
                         int c)
        Note: as of now not in use because the global candidate list is not utilized within the getBlockxPairCells methods. This method fetches the cells from the global list getBlockPairCells (which are just the two cells of the minimal Pair in a block) and compares their coordinates. If and only if they share a column or a row, clear the candidate lists of all cells that are in the same column or row.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid.
        r - The row.
        c - The column.

      • fillHiddenCell

        public void fillHiddenCell(Grid grid,
                           int r,
                           int c)
        This method looks for the first unit in the grid with a hidden single cell and fills it using the getBlockMinimalHiddenSingleCell method.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid.
        r - The row.
        c - The column.

      • fillNakedSingle

        public void fillNakedSingle(Grid grid,
                            int r,
                            int c)
        This method looks for the first unit in the grid with a naked naked cell and fills it using the getBlockNakedSingleCell method.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid to fill.
        r - The row.
        c - The column.

      • fillFullHouse

        public void fillFullHouse(Grid grid)
        This method looks for the first unit in the grid with a full house cell and fills it using the getBlockNakedSingleCell method. A full house cell is also a naked single cell.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid to fill.

      • completeAndValid

        public boolean completeAndValid(Grid grid)
        This method stands for "Schritt 1" in the BlockBasedSolver pseudo-code and checks first whether the whole grid is valid. Then it checks if it is filled.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid to check.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the grid is both complete and valid.

      • createGlobalList

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>[][] createGlobalList(Grid grid)
        This method fills all the candidate lists for the empty cells with all the numbers 1-9. Then, by checking if a certain number k appears somewhere in the grid, it removes the number k from the candidate lists of all the cells in the same row, column and block.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid.
        Returns:
        Returns the 81 candidate array lists in a two-dimensional array.

      • removeCandidatesSameRow

        public void removeCandidatesSameRow(Grid grid,
                                    int r,
                                    int k,
                                    java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>[] list)
        Note: as of now not in use. Called by the update method. The method goes through all the cells in the row where a cell is already populated with a number k and removes k from their candidate lists.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid.
        r - The row to check.
        k - The number to look for in the candidate lists.
        list - A part of the global list for the row r.

      • removeCandidatesSameCol

        public void removeCandidatesSameCol(Grid grid,
                                    int c,
                                    int k,
                                    java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>[][] list)
        Note: as of now not in use. Called by the update method. The method goes through all the cells in the column where a cell is already populated with a number k and removes k from their candidate lists.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid.
        c - The column to check.
        k - The number to look for in the candidate lists.
        list - Here the complete List is being passed on and the column is specified within the method

      • removeCandidatesSameBlock

        public void removeCandidatesSameBlock(Grid grid,
                                      int r,
                                      int c,
                                      int k,
                                      java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>[][] list)
        Note: as of now not in use. The method goes through all the cells in the block where a cell is already populated with a number k and removes k from their candidate lists. It makes use of the method getAnchorCoords, which helps identify the anchor cell of the block with which to initiate the check.
        Parameters:
        grid - The current grid.
        c - The column to check.
        r - The column to check.
        k - The number to look for in the candidate lists.
        list - Here the complete List is being passed on and the column is specified within the method.

      • getAnchorCoords

        public int[] getAnchorCoords(int r,
                             int c)
        A support method which identifies the coordinates of the block anchor cell for any cell in the grid. E.g. if input=6,5, it will return the coordinates of the anchor, which is 4,4
        Parameters:
        r - The row of the input cell.
        c - The column of the input cell.
        Returns:
        The coordinates of the anchor cell.
